text: Applications
ACE 3-1
For each situation, find the number of coins in each pouch. Each pouch contains the same number of $1 gold coins, and the total number of coins on each side of the equation is the same.

a. 4 coins

b. 5 coins

c. 1 coin

d. 0 coins
ACE 3-2

Carter used the following equations to find some information about three walkathon pledge plans.

Plan 1:

14 = 2x

Plan 2:

y = 3.5(10) + 10

Plan 3:

100 = 1.5x + 55

In each equation y is the amount donated in dollars, and x is the number of kilometers walked. For each equation, answer the following:

a. What information is Carter trying to find?

b. Describe how you could find the information.

a. Plan 1: Looking for the number of kilometers walked to get a $14 donation.

Plan 2: Looking for how much a donation will be for walking 10 kilometers.

Plan 3: Looking for the number of kilometers walked to get a $100 donation.

b.

Plan 1: Solve for x.

14 รท 2 = 2x รท 2

7 = x

Plan 2: Evaluate the expression.

y = 3.5(10) + 10

y = 35 + 10

y = 45

Plan 3: Solve for x.

100 - 55 = 1.5x + 55 - 55

45 = 1.5x

45 รท 1.5 = 1.5x รท 1.5

30 = x
ACE 3-3
For each equation, sketch a picture using pouches and coins. Then, determine how many coins are in a pouch.

a. Pictures will vary, but should include 3 pouches on the left side of the equation and 12 coins on the right side of the equation; x = 4.

b. Pictures will vary, but should include 2 pouches and 5 coins on the left side of the equation and 19 coins on the right side of the equation; x = 7.

c. Pictures will vary, but should include 4 pouches and 5 coins on the left side of the equation and 2 pouches and 19 coins on the right side of the equation; x = 7.

d. Pictures will vary, but should include 1 pouch and 12 coins on the left side of the equation and 2 pouches and 6 coins on the right side of the equation; x = 6.

e. Pictures will vary, but should include 3 pouches and 12 coins on the left side of the equation and 18 coins on the right side of the equation; x = 2.
ACE 3-4

Multiple Choice

Which of the following is a solution to the equation 11 = โ3x โ 10?

A. 1.3

B. -1/3

C. โ7

D. 24
C. -7
ACE 3-5

Determine whether each expression is always, sometimes, or never equal to โ2(x โ 3).

a. โ2x + 6

b. โ2xโ6

c. 2x + 6

d. โ2xโ3

e. โ2(x + 3)

f. 2(3 โ x)

a. always equal: โ2(x โ 3) = โ2x + 6

b. never equal (the expressions differ by 12)

c. sometimes equal (only equal for x = 0)

d. never equal (the expressions differ by 9)

e. never equal (the expressions differ by 12)

f. always equal: 2(3 โ x) = 6 โ 2x = โ2x + 6
ACE 3-6

Use properties of equality and numbers to solve each equation for x. Check your answers.

a. 7 + 3x = 5x + 13

b. 3xโ7 = 5x + 13

c. 7โ3x = 5x + 13

d. 3x + 7 = 5xโ13

e. 3x + 5 = 20

f. 3x โ 5 = 20

g. 3x + 5 = -20

h. -3x + 5 = 20

i. -3x โ 5 = -20

a. x = -3

b. x = -10

c. x = - 6/8 or -3/4

d. x = 10

e. x = 5

f. x = 8โ

g. -8โ

h. x = -5

i. x = 5
ACE 3-7

Solve each equation for x.

a. 2x + 6 = 6x + 2

b. 2x + 6 = 6x โ 2

c. 2x โ 6 = โ6x + 2

d. โ2x โ 6 = โ6x โ 2

a. x = 1

b. x = 2

c. x = 1

d. x = 1
ACE 3-8

Solve each equation for x.

a. 3(x + 2) = 12

b. 3(x + 2 = x โ 18

c. 3(x + 2) = 2x

d. 3(x + 2) = -15

e. 5 โ 2(x โ 1) = 12

f. 5 + 2(x โ 1) = 12

g. 5 โ 2(x + 2) = 12

h. 5 โ 2x + 2 = 12

a. x = 2

b. x = -12

c. x = -6

d. x = -7

e. x = -2.5

f. x = 4.5

g. x = -5.5

h. x = -2.5
ACE 3-9

Use the equation P = 10 โ 2.5c.

a. Find P when c = 3.2.

b. Find c when P = 85.

c. Describe how you can use a table or a graph to answer parts (a.) and (b.).

a. P = 2

b. c = -30

c. You could use a table by trying to find the P-value for every value of c. You could use the graph by finding the coordinates of points on the line. You would go over to c on the x-axis (the axis representing the variable c), and then go up or down on the y-axis (representing the variable P) until you reach the line, and read the value of P. You can do the same thing to find the c-value, either by looking up all values in a chart that give you either a particular c- or P-value or by finding coordinate pairs by using the graph.

Use the equation m = 15.75 + 3.2d. Find m for each value of d.

a. d = 20

b. d = 0

c. d = 3.2

a. m = 79.75

b. m = 15.75

c. m = 25.99

Use the equation m = 15.75 + 3.2d. Find d for each value of m.

a. m = 54.15

b. m = 0

c. m = 100

a. d = 12

b. d = -4.921875

c. d = 26.328125
ACE 3-12

Find all the values of x for each inequality. Explain your strategy.

a. 3x โ 7 < -9

b. 3x - 7 > -5

c. 2x + 1 > -3

d. 2x + 1 < -3

e. -3x - 1 < 4

f. -3x โ 1 > -4

a. x < -2/3

b. x > 2/3

c. x > -2

d. x < -2

e. x > -5/3

f. x < 1

Note: Student' strategies will vary, but will likely include solving the associated equality and then testing values for x to determine the direction of inequality.
ACE 3-13

Consider the inequality y > 2x + 7

a. What are the possible values for y if x=1?

b. What are the possible values for x if y=10?

c. Describe how you can use a table or a graph to answer parts a and b.

a. y > 9

b. x < 1.5

c. You could fill out a table for the relationship and find out which pair of (x, y) values solve the related inequality. Then all the values on one side of that table entry will satisfy the relationship. You could graph the related equality and find the x-value that you are looking for and its associated y-value. Then all other y-values that are further up on the graphed line will also satisfy the relationship. You could switch this order for part b.
ACE 3-14

Describe how you could use a graph or a table to solve each equation.

a. 5x + 10 = โ20

b. 4x โ 9 = โ7x + 13

a. To solve 5x + 10 = โ20, use the equation 5x + 10 = y. To use a table, scan down the table of y-values until you come to โ20. The corresponding x-value is the solution. To use a graph, graph the equation 5x + 10 = y until you have a point whose y-coordinate is โ20. The corresponding x-coordinate (x = โ6) is the solution.

b. To solve this equation by graphing, graph the lines y = 4x โ 9 and y = โ7x + 13. At the point where the graphs cross, the x-coordinate is the solution. To solve using a table, create a table for the left side and right side and look for an ordered pair (x, y) that shows up on both tables. The x-coordinate of this ordered pair will be the solution.
ACE 3-15

The expenses E and income I for making and selling T-shirts with a school logo are given by the equations E = 535 + 4.50n and I = 12n, where n is the number of T-shirts.

a. How many T-shirts must be made and sold to break even? Explain.

b. Suppose only 50 shirts are sold. Is there a profit or a loss? Explain.

c. Suppose the income is $1,200. Is there a profit or a loss? Explain.

d. Write an inequality and use a number line to represent the number of T-shirts that need to be made and sold in order to make a profit.

a. 72 T-shirts must be made and sold to break even. By setting the expressions for E and I equal to each other, you obtain 535 + 4.5n = 12n. Solving for n gives n = 71.3.

b. A loss, because the expenses, which are 535 + 4.5(50) = $760, exceed the income, which is 12(50) = $600.

c. There is a profit because when the income is $1,200, the number of T-shirts is 100. When the number of T-shirts is 100, the expenses are $ 985. Whenever the expenses are less than the income, there is a profit.

d. To make a profit you need to have I > E, or 12n > 535 + 4.5n. On a number line this inequality is represented:
ACE 3-16

Students at Hammond Middle School are raising money for the end-of-year school party. They decide to sell roses for Valentine's Day. The students can buy the roses for 50 cents each from a wholesaler. They also need $60 to buy ribbon and paper to protect the roses as well as materials for advertising the sale. They sell each rose for $1.30.

a. How many roses must they sell to break even? Explain.

b. What is the students' profit if they sell 50 roses? 100 roses? 200 roses?

a. They must sell 75 roses to break even. By setting the expressions for cost and income equal to each other, you obtain 0.5n + 60 = 1.3n. Solving for n gives n = 75.

b. They do not make a profit, but have a loss of $20, when they sell 50 roses. They make a profit of $20 when they sell 100 roses. They make a profit of $100 when they sell 200 roses.
ACE 3-17

Represent the solution to each inequality on a number line.

a. 3x + 3 < 3

b. 5x < 10

c. 2x โ 1 > 4

d. 2x โ 1 < 4
Connections
ACE 3-18

Describe what operations are indicated in each expression. Then, write each expression as a single number.

a. โ8(4)

b. โ2 ยท 4

c. 6(โ5) โ 10

d. 2(โ2) + 3(5)

a. multiplication; โ32

b. multiplication; โ8

c. multiplication and then subtraction; โ40

d. multiplication (twice) and then addition; 11
ACE 3-19

Decide whether each pair of quantities is equal. Explain your reasoning.

a. 6(5) + 2 and 6(5 + 2)

b. 8 โ 3x and 3x โ 8

c. 4 + 5 and 5 + 4

d. โ2(3) and 3(โ2)

e. 3 โ 5 and 5 โ 3

f. 2 quarters and 5 dimes

g. 1.5 liters and 15 milliliters

h. 2 out of 5 students prefer wearing sneakers to school and 50% of the students prefer wearing sneakers to school

a. No; in the first expression, only 5 is multiplied by 6, but in the second expression, both 5 and 2 are multiplied by 6.

b. No; they are opposites of each other.

c. Yes; they are equal because of the Commutative Property of Addition.

d. Yes; they are equal because of the Commutative Property of Multiplication.

e. No; they are not equal because of the Commutative Property of Subtraction.

f. Yes; they are both worth 50 cents.

g. No; 1.5 liters equals 1,500 milliliters, not 15 milliliters.

h. No; 2 out of 5 is 40, not 50.
ACE 3-20
Write two different expressions to represent the area of each rectangle.

a. A = x(5 + 4); A = 5x + 4x

b. A = 1.5(7 + x); A = 10.5 + 1.5x
ACE 3-21

For parts (a.) and (b.), find the mystery number and explain your reasoning.

a. If you add 15 to 3 times the mystery number, you get 78. What is the mystery number?

b. If you subtract 27 from 5 times the mystery number, you get 83. What is the mystery number?

c. Make up clues for a riddle whose mystery number is 9.

a. x = 21; you can use the equation 3x + 15 = 78 to represent the given information. Subtract 15 from each side of the equation to get 3x = 63, and then divide each side by 3.

b. x = 22; you can use the equation 5x โ 27 = 83 to represent the given information. Add 27 to each side of the equation to get 5x = 110, and then divide each side by 5.

c. Answers will vary. Sample answer: If you add 6 to 9 times the mystery number, you get 87. The mystery number is 9.
ACE 3-22
Two students' solutions to the equation 6(x + 4) = 3x โ 2 are shown below. Both students made an error. Find the errors and give a correct solution.

Student 1 subtracted 6 from the righthand side, instead of distributing the 6 throughout the parenthesis on the left-hand side (used subtraction to undo multiplication). Student 2 started to distribute the 6 throughout the parenthesis on the left-hand side, but only did it to the first term and forgot to do it to the second one (it should be 24, as opposed to 4). The correct solution is x = -8โ.
ACE 3-23
Two students' solutions to the equation 58.5 = 3.5x โ 6 are shown below. Both students made an error. Find the errors and give a correct solution.

Student 1: The first step is incorrect. Instead of subtracting 6, the student should have added 6. The correct answer is 64.5 รท 3.4 โ 18.43.

Student 2: The studentโs answer is wrong due to incorrect placement of the decimal point. The answer is approximately 18.4.
ACE 3-24

Gilberto's grandfather gives him $5 for his birthday and then 50ยข for each math question he answers correctly on his math exams for the year.

a. Write an equation that represents the amount of money that Gilberto receives during a school year. Explain what the variables and numbers mean.

b. Use the equation to find the number of correct answers Gilberto needs to buy a new shirt that costs $25. Show your work.

c. Gilberto answered all 12 problems correctly on his first math exam. How much money is he assured of receiving for the year? Show your work.

a. y = 5 + 0.50x. Here x stands for the number of math questions Gilberto gets right, y stands for the total amount of money his grandfather gives him, 5 stands for the birthday money Gilberto gets even if he never answers a single question correctly, and 0.50 stands for the $.50 he gets for every question he gets right.

b. To buy a shirt that costs $25, we need to solve the equation:

25 = 5 + 0.50x

20 = 0.50x

x = 40

So, he will need to answer 40 questions correctly to buy the shirt.

Note: We anticipate that students may use other methods to solve this problem. It might be nice to discuss this exercise as a class to reinforce the idea that solving these kinds of problems algebraically yields the same answer as solving with a table or graph.

c. y = 5 + 0.50(12)

y = 5 + 6

y = 11

So, he will make $11.

Note: Again, students may use tables or graphs to solve this problem. Make sure they understand that they can also solve this problem by substituting 12 for x.

Note: You can have students compare this to the equation for Alanaโs pledge plan. They are the same, but each represents a different context.
ACE 3-25

The number of times a cricket chirps in a minute is related to the temperature. You can use the formula:

n = 4t - 160

to determine the number of chirps n a cricket makes in a minute when the temperature is t degrees Fahrenheit. If you want to estimate the temperature by counting cricket chirps, you can use the following form of the equation:

t = ยผ n + 40

a. At 60 degrees F, how many times does a cricket chirp in a minute?

b. What is the temperature if a cricket chirps 150 times in a minute?

c. At what temperature does a cricket stop chirping?

d. Sketch a graph of the equation with number of chirps on the x-axis and temperature on the y-axis. What information do the y-intercept of the graph and the coefficient of n give you?

a. n = 4(60) โ 160 = 80 chirps

b. t = ยผ (150) + 40 = 77.5ยฐF

c. This would be when the number of chirps is 0:

t = ยผ (0) + 40 = 40ยฐF.

d. The y-intercept gives the temperature when the number of chirps is 0. The coefficient of n means the ratio of the change in temperature to the change in number of chirps.

Note: An interesting question to raise is, โIf the graph were extended to the left, what meaning would that part have?โ
ACE 3-26
Khong thinks he has a different way to solve equations, by first factoring out both sides of the equation by the greatest common factor. This is how he solved the first equation in Problem 3.3.

a. Is Khong correct, that this method works for this problem? Explain.

b. Use Khong's method to solve the equation 40x + 20 = 120.

c. Khong says his method won't work to solve 7x + 3 = 31. Why is that?

d. Write an equation that can be solved using Khong's method. Then solve your equation.

a. Yes, Khongโs method is correct. A factored expression is equivalent to the original expression, and dividing both sides of an equation by the same number results in another equivalent equation.

b. 40x + 20 = 120

20(2x + 1) = 20(6)

2x + 1 = 6

2x = 5

x = 5/2 = 2ยฝ

c. Khong is partially correct: his method does not work as well because all the numbers are prime. However, he could still factor out the GCF, which is 1. He could also factor out another number but would get fractions in the new equation. For example, Khong could factor out seven to get 7(x +3/7) = 7(31/7).

d. Answers will vary. Sample answer:

12x + 24 = 48

12(x + 2) = 12(4)

x + 2 = 4

x = 2
ACE 3-27

a. Use fact families to write a related sentence for nโ(โ3) = 30. Does this related sentence make it easier to find the value for n? Why or why not?

b. Use fact families to write a related sentence for 5 + n = โ36. Does this related sentence make it easier to find the value for n? Why or why not?

c. Solve the equations in parts (a.) and (b.) using properties of equality. How does this method compare to using the fact families?

a. n = 30 + โ3 or n = 30 โ 3, โ3 = n โ 30 or 3 = 30 โ n.

Answers will vary. Some students may think n = 30 โ 3 is easier, while other students may not.

b. 5 = โ36 โ n or n = โ36 โ 5. Answers will vary. Some students may think n = โ36 โ 5 is easier, while other students may not.

c. For part (a.), add โ3 to both sides; n = 27.

For part (b.), subtract 5 from both sides; n = โ41.

Answers will vary. Some students may find fact families easier; others may find the properties of equality easier.
ACE 3-28

The higher the altitude, the colder the temperature. The formula T = t โ d/150 is used to estimate the temperature T at different altitudes, where t is the ground temperature in degrees Celsius and d is the altitude in meters.

a. Suppose the ground temperature is 0 degrees Celsius. What is the temperature at an altitude of 1,500 meters?

b. Suppose the temperature at 300 meters is 26 degrees Celsius. What is the ground temperature?

a. T = 0 โ 1500/150 = 0 โ 10 = โ10ยฐC

b. 26 = t โ 300/150 = t โ 2; thus t = 28ยฐC
ACE 3-29
In each part below, identify the equations that have the same solution.

a. Part (A) is about recognizing notation.

For example, โ1x = โx.

A & D: x = 8;

B & F: x = โ8;

C & E: x = 2

b. G, J, M: x = 7;

H, K, L: x = โ5

c. N & P: x = 4.5;

O & Q: x = โ8;

R & S: x = โ3.5

Use the equation y = 4 โ 3x and find y when:

a. x = 4

b. x = โ3

c. x = 2

d. x = -4/3

e. x = 0

a. y = -8

b. y = 13

c. y = -2

d. y = 8

e. y = 4
ACE 3-31

Use the equation y = 4 โ 3x and find x when:

a. y = 0

b. y = 21

c. y = โ15

d. y = 3.5

a. x = 4/3

b. x = -5โ

c. x = 6โ

d. x = โ
ACE 3-32
Explain how the information you found for ACE 3-30 and 3-31 relates to locating points on a line representing y = 4 โ 3x.
You can look at either the x-axis or the y-axis to find the other coordinate pair by using the graph made by the line y = 4 โ 3x.
ACE 3-33

Fill in the missing representation for each inequality (symbols, number line, words).

Note: You can drag blank numbe rlines into a drawing tool then draw your own inequality.
Symbols:
Number Lines:
Words:
a. x > -4
a.
b. x โค 2
b. All numbers less than or equal to 2
c. 3 < x
c.
d.
d.
e.
e. All numbers greater than negative 3

a. all numbers greater than -4

b. See number line b below

c. all numbers greater than 3; see number line c below

d. x โค 3; all numbers less than or equal to 3

e. x > -3; see number line e below
Extensions
ACE 3-34

The maximum weight allowed in an elevator is 1,500 pounds.

a. The average weight per adult is 150 pounds, and the average weight per child is 40 pounds. Write an equation for the number of adults A and the number of children C the elevator can hold.

b. Suppose ten children are in the elevator. How many adults can get in?

c. Suppose six adults are in the elevator. How many children can get in?
ACE 3-35

Wind can affect the speed of an airplane. Suppose a plane is flying round-trip from New York City to San Francisco. The plane has a cruising speed of 300 miles per hour. The wind is blowing from west to east at 30 miles per hour. When the plane flies into (in the opposite direction of) the wind, its speed decreases by 30 miles per hour. When the plane flies with (in the same direction as) the wind, its speed increases by 30 miles per hour.

tiles.title: New York City to San Francisco

text: a. Make a table that shows the total time the plane has traveled after each 200-mile interval on its trip from New York City to San Francisco and back.

b. For each direction, write an equation for the distance d traveled in t hours.

c. On the same set of axes, sketch graphs of the time and distance data for travel in each direction.

d. How long does it take a plane to fly 5,000 miles against a 30-mile-per-hour wind? With a 30-mile-per-hour wind? Explain how you found your answers.

b. NY to SF: d = 270t;

SF to NY: d = 330t
d. Against the wind: 5,000 รท 270 = 18.52 h; with the wind: 5,000 รท 330 = 15.15 h
ACE 3-36

Solve each equation. Explain what your answers might mean.

a. 2(x + 3) = 3x + 3

b. 2(x + 3) = 2x + 6

c. 2(x + 3) = 2x + 3

a. x = 3 (x equals an exact number, which is 3, to make both sides of the expression equal.)

b. x = any number. For any value of x, the value of each side of the equation is the sameโthe two expressions are equivalent.

c. No solution. For any value of x, the value of the left side is 3 more than the value of the right side.
ACE 3-37
Students in Mr. Rickman's class are asked to solve the equation . Look at the three solutions below. Are they correct? Explain which method makes the most sense to you.

All three methods are correct. The advantage in Jessโs solution is getting rid of the fractions first by distributing. Another way to do this is what Terri did, multiplying the equation by 3. Brian noticed that the expression in both sets of parentheses is the same, so he is correct that he can simplify the left side to 6x โ 9.
ACE 3-38

Multiple Choice

Dorine solves the equation 3x + 3 = 3x + 9 and is trying to make sense of her answer.

Which of the following should Dorine say is the correct solution?

A. x = 6, because 6 is the final number in the equation.

B. x = 6 or x = 0, because both of these numbers are in the last equation.

C. There is no solution, because each value of x will lead to 0 = 6, which is not true.

D. The solution is all numbers, because x will satisfy the equation.
C is the correct answer. The expression on the right side will always be 6 greater than the expression on the left because the left side is adding 3 to 3x, whereas the right side is adding 9 to 3x.
ACE 3-39

Multiple Choice

Flora solves this equation:

3(x + 1) = 3x + 3

Flora uses the following method.

Which of the following should Flora say is the correct solution?

A. x = 0, since 0 = 0 is the last line of the equation.

B. No solution, because x does not show up in the equation 0 = 0.

C. Any number x will work.
C is the correct answer. This equation is an identity. 3(x + 1) is equivalent to 3x + 3.
ACE 3-40

Fill in the missing representation for each inequality.

Note: You can drag blank numbe rlines into a drawing tool then draw your own inequality.
In Symbols:
On a Number Line:
In Words:
a.
a. all positive numbers
b. x2 < 9
b. all numbers whose square are less than 9
c.
c. all numbers whose absolute values are greater than or equal to 2
d. x3 > x
d. all numbers for which the cube of the number is greater than the number itself
e. x + (1/x) > 1
e. all numbers for which the sum of the number and its reciprocal is greater than 1

a. x > 0

b. any number greater than -3 and less then 3; see number line b below

c. |x| โฅ 2; see number line c below

d. any number greater than one, or between -1 and 0.; see number line d below

e. All negative numbers will have negative sums, so those are excluded. Any number greater than 1 will work, but any number between 0 and 1 also works because 1x will be greater than 1. See number line e below.
ACE 3-41
Frank thinks he can solve inequalities the same way he can solve equations. He uses the method shown below.

a. Does Frank's method work in general for other inequalities?

b. Frank runs into some difficulties trying to solve the following problem:

-2x + 1 > 5

-2x > 4

He thinks the answer is x > โ2. He knows that if this is true, then x = 0 should be a solution, because 0 > โ2. But when he checks his work, he notices that โ2(0) + 1 โฏ 5. What numbers should be solutions for the original inequality?

a. Frankโs method works in general, except for multiplying and dividing by a negative number. This requires flipping the inequality sign, which is the issue in part (b.).

b. The inequality โ2x > 4 is equivalent to the inequality 2x < โ4. One way to see this is to add 2x โ 4 to both sides of โ2x > 4. Thus, we see that โ4 > 2x or x < โ2. That is, all numbers less than โ2 are solutions of the original inequality. In general, multiplying or dividing both sides of an inequality by a negative number reverses the direction of the inequality.
